entry.title: Automating a Simple SAP Lab Environment with Terraform and Ansible
entry.content:
This walkthrough demonstrates how to provision a lightweight SLES instance using Terraform, then automatically configure it using Ansible. The result is a clean, automated pipeline that can build and prepare a small SAP-style lab environment in minutes.

All identifying information (AWS account details, VPC IDs, Subnets, AMI IDs, SSH key names, IP addresses, etc.) is represented using placeholders.

Overview

This setup uses two main components:

1. Terraform (Infrastructure)

  • A SLES EC2 instance
  • A minimal security group
  • An SSH key pair reference
  • An Ansible-ready inventory line (via Terraform outputs)

2. Ansible (Configuration)

  • Basic packages
  • chronyd for time synchronisation
  • Simple SAP-friendly sysctl tuning

No SAP software is installed here. This is a lightweight foundation for further SAP experimentation.

Directory Structure

sap-lab/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ run.sh
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ run_destroy.sh
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ terraform/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.tf
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ <SSH_PUBLIC_KEY_FILENAME>.pub
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ terraform.tfstate   (generated automatically)
‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ansible/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ inventory.ini
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ site.yml
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ansible.cfg

Terraform: main.tf

The following main.tf provisions a SLES instance and generates an Ansible inventory line.

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.5"

  required_providers {
    aws = {
      source  = "hashicorp/aws"
      version = "~> 5.0"
    }
  }
}

provider "aws" {
  region = "<AWS_REGION>"   # e.g. us-east-2
}

resource "aws_key_pair" "ssh_key" {
  key_name   = "<KEY_NAME>"                       # e.g. sap-lab-key
  public_key = file("${path.module}/<SSH_PUBLIC_KEY_FILENAME>.pub")
}

resource "aws_security_group" "sap_host_sg" {
  name        = "sap-host-sg"
  description = "Security group for SAP lab host"
  vpc_id      = "<VPC_ID>"

  ingress {
    from_port   = 22
    to_port     = 22
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]   # adjust for production
  }

  egress {
    from_port   = 0
    to_port     = 0
    protocol    = "-1"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  tags = {
    Name = "sap-host-sg"
  }
}

resource "aws_instance" "sap_host" {
  ami           = "<SLES_AMI_ID>"                # generic placeholder
  instance_type = "t2.micro"
  key_name      = aws_key_pair.ssh_key.key_name

  subnet_id                   = "<SUBNET_ID>"
  associate_public_ip_address = true

  vpc_security_group_ids = [
    aws_security_group.sap_host_sg.id
  ]

  tags = {
    Name = "SAP-LAB-Host"
  }
}

output "ansible_inventory_line" {
  description = "Ansible inventory line for this host"
  value = "sap_host ansible_host=<EC2_PUBLIC_IP> ansible_user=ec2-user ansible_ssh_private_key_file=<PATH_TO_PRIVATE_KEY>/<SSH_PRIVATE_KEY_FILENAME>.pem ansible_ssh_common_args='-o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null'"
}

Ansible: site.yml

---
- name: Prepare host for SAP-style workloads
  hosts: sap_hosts
  become: true

  tasks:
    - name: Install basic packages
      ansible.builtin.zypper:
        name:
          - wget
          - net-tools
          - chrony
        state: present

    - name: Ensure chronyd is enabled and running
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: chronyd
        state: started
        enabled: yes

    - name: Set SAP-friendly sysctl values
      ansible.posix.sysctl:
        name: vm.swappiness
        value: "10"
        state: present
        reload: yes

Ansible: inventory.ini

[sap_hosts]
sap_host ansible_host=<EC2_PUBLIC_IP> ansible_user=ec2-user ansible_ssh_private_key_file=<PATH_TO_PRIVATE_KEY>/<SSH_PRIVATE_KEY_FILENAME>.pem ansible_ssh_common_args='-o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null'

Automation script: run.sh

#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -e

echo "=== Terraform apply ==="
cd terraform
terraform init -input=false
terraform apply -auto-approve -input=false

echo "=== Extracting host info for Ansible ==="
INVENTORY_LINE=$(terraform output -raw ansible_inventory_line)

cd ../ansible

echo "=== Writing inventory.ini ==="
{
  echo "[sap_hosts]"
  echo "$INVENTORY_LINE"
} > inventory.ini

echo "=== Running Ansible playbook ==="
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini site.yml

Automation script: run_destroy.sh

#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -e

echo "=== Terraform destroy ==="
cd terraform
terraform destroy -auto-approve -input=false
cd ..

echo "=== Clearing Ansible inventory ==="
echo "# Inventory cleared after destroy" > ansible/inventory.ini

Running the lab

Build the environment

./run.sh

Destroy the environment

./run_destroy.sh

Conclusion

This tutorial provides a simple, repeatable way to spin up SAP-friendly Linux hosts on AWS: Terraform handles the infrastructure, and Ansible handles configuration. From here, you can extend the playbook with SAP Host Agent installation, Cloud Connector setup, or full SAP system preparation, while keeping the core workflow automated and reproducible.

entry.title: Re: Seeking Guidance on EWM RF Program Navigation Challenges
entry.content:
Have you configured your 'logical transactions' in the EWM-Customizing?
Please check the Customizing related to Transaction - StepProcess - etc. (You could use a FunctionCode "SKIP" or pass teh logic to move to a different FunctionCode on the Second attempt?)

Also, consider using the Class "/SCWM/CL_RF_BLL_SRVC=>SET_PRMOD" and "/SCWM/CL_RF_BLL_SRVC=>SET_FCODE" ...

Check the following interesting resources :

  • Please check SAP-Note 3428038 - RF Framework: Best practices to create a custom enhancement - SAP for Me
  • Link RF (PDF) : RadioFrequency_v3.1.pdf
  • On the SAP Community : Customer enhancement in EWM: Skipping a screen in ... - SAP Community

Hope this helps ...

Nic T.

entry.title: Ready to master SAP Commerce Cloud?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Implementing SAP Commerce Cloud learning journey. 
This journey is structured across three sub-courses, combining theoretical knowledge and practical experience to ensure you can successfully implement SAP Commerce Cloud in real-world scenarios.

What you'll learn

SAP Commerce Cloud Fundamentals

  • Understand the fundamental technical aspects of SAP Commerce Cloud.

  • Configure essential settings and perform basic customizations.

Customizing and Developing SAP Commerce Cloud

  • Customize and develop essential parts of SAP Commerce Cloud.
  • Integrate custom features to meet specific business needs.

Deploying and Extending SAP Commerce Cloud Solutions

  • Deploy your solutions to the cloud.
  • Configure advanced features like storefront customization, promotions, searching, and web services.

Learning outcomes

After completing this journey, you will be able to:

  1. Understand and Configure SAP Commerce Cloud for optimal performance.
  2. Customize and Develop essential components to enhance functionality.
  3. Deploy Solutions to the cloud seamlessly.
  4. Configure and Extend advanced features for a superior customer experience.

Prove your skills and earn a certification that validates your expertise. 
Join us today and embark on a transformative learning experience!


Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: Fast & Curious: The Making of an SAP Champion
entry.content:
On a Saturday morning in Hyderabad, Ruthvik Chowdary might be cruising towards a new destination with his playlist ready or volunteering at an SAP Inside Track event. Whether navigating winding roads or meeting fellow tech enthusiasts, Ruthvik thrives on exploring places, ideas, and opportunities.

That same spirit of discovery led him to SAP technology.

Inspired by his uncle, an experienced SAP Solution Architect, Ruthvik‚Äôs curiosity sparked during college. ‚ÄúHe would discuss the problems he solved and SAP‚Äôs impact on businesses. It made him want to dive in.‚Äù And with his growing interest in manufacturing, it became the perfect starting point.

Guided by mentors and managers, Ruthvik soon broadened his expertise across the entire supply chain. He earned SAP Certifications spanning SAP Quality Management to SAP Extended Warehouse Management and now, as a Supply Chain Manager at Deloitte, confidently designs and optimizes end-to-end processes.

His breakthrough came during a training with a simulated supply bottleneck where he applied his knowledge to solve it. ‚ÄúThat was when everything clicked. I understood not just the ‚Äòhow,‚Äô but the ‚Äòwhy.‚Äô It was empowering.‚Äù

The path, however, was not without challenges. Ruthvik wrestled with complex configurations and moments of self-doubt early in his journey. ‚ÄúI wondered if I was really suited for SAP products.‚Äù Encouragement from his mentor, manager, and uncle reminded him that every expert starts as a beginner.

What continues to amaze him is SAP‚Äôs vastness and the constant innovation in cloud technologies. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like an ocean. There‚Äôs always something new to learn.‚Äù Along the way, he developed unexpected strengths in communication and client engagement, becoming a trusted problem solver and mentor to others.

One of his proudest moments was being recognized as an SAP Champion for his contributions to the community. ‚ÄúKnowing my blogs helped others, even in interviews, is incredibly rewarding.‚Äù

From shadow consultant to SAP Champion, Ruthvik‚Äôs story is one of persistence, passion, and purpose. His advice to new learners is simple: ‚ÄúDive in, stay curious, and do not be afraid to ask for help. The rewards are worth it.‚Äù

Ready to begin your own adventure? Explore structured learning journeys and certifications on the SAP Learning site and discover where curiosity can take you.

entry.title: Re: job requisition route maps are not correct
entry.content:
This can happen if you are creating the job requisition from position org chart where the operator role has not been populated via the rule. 

Example Route map uses the operator R G S you create the requisition from the position and map the Roles for R & G but not the S. When you go to the route map on the requisition you route map will only show R & G. 

KBA explains the behavior

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002479444

entry.title: Re: ALV TREE: Select ALL - Deselect ALL
entry.content:
Ok, As Sandra said in the other thread the key is play with the item layout.

I've created two custom buttons to mark and unmark all the nodes. 
In my internal table GT_PEDIDOS I have the node key in the field NODO.
This is my solution:

FORM mark_all .

  DATA:
    ls_item_layout   TYPE lvc_s_laci.

  PERFORM item_layout USING abap_true CHANGING ls_item_layout.

  LOOP AT gt_pedidos ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_pedidos>)
    WHERE nodo IS NOT INITIAL.

    CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->change_item
      EXPORTING
        i_node_key     = <ls_pedidos>-nodo
        i_fieldname    = c_campo_seleccion
        i_data         = abap_false
*       i_u_data       = abap_true
        is_item_layout = ls_item_layout
      EXCEPTIONS
        node_not_found = 1
        OTHERS         = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
*     Implement suitable error handling here
    ENDIF.

  ENDLOOP.

  CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->frontend_update.

ENDFORM.

FORM unmark_all.

  DATA:
    ls_item_layout   TYPE lvc_s_laci,
    lt_selected_node TYPE lvc_t_chit.

  CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->get_checked_items
    IMPORTING
      et_checked_items = lt_selected_node.

  PERFORM item_layout USING abap_false CHANGING ls_item_layout.

  LOOP AT lt_selected_node ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_node>).

    CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->change_item
      EXPORTING
        i_node_key     = <ls_node>-nodekey
        i_fieldname    = 'MARK'
        i_data         = abap_false
*       i_u_data       = abap_true
        is_item_layout = ls_item_layout
      EXCEPTIONS
        node_not_found = 1
        OTHERS         = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
*     Implement suitable error handling here
    ENDIF.

  ENDLOOP.

  CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->frontend_update.

ENDFORM.

FORM item_layout USING p_lv_mark
                 CHANGING p_ls_layout TYPE lvc_s_laci.

  p_ls_layout-fieldname  = c_campo_seleccion.
  p_ls_layout-class      = cl_gui_column_tree=>item_class_checkbox.
  p_ls_layout-u_class    = abap_true.
  p_ls_layout-editable   = abap_true.
  p_ls_layout-u_editable = abap_true.
  p_ls_layout-u_chosen   = abap_true.

  p_ls_layout-chosen     = p_lv_mark.

ENDFORM.

entry.title: Material availability check in maintenance orders ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello community,

We are working in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and have a question regarding material availability in maintenance orders.

In our scenario:

  • The required materials are stored in the warehouse.

  • When creating a maintenance order, we would like the system to indicate directly within the order whether the materials are available or not.

  • Additionally, if materials are not available, we would like the order status to be updated automatically to ‚ÄúMaterial shortage‚Äù.

So far, we have not found how to configure this availability check inside the maintenance order in the Public Cloud environment.

Is there a standard functionality in S/4HANA Public Cloud that shows material availability directly in the maintenance order and updates the status accordingly?

Or would this require additional configuration or process adjustments (e.g., reservations management, order customizing)?

Thank you very much for your support!

entry.title: Re: Change Custom Font Family using UI Theme Designer
entry.content:
See SAP KBA 2812695 - How to Change the Default Font in UI Theme Designer

Resolution

  1. Upgrade UI Theme Designer to the latest version as per Note 2119552 - UI Theme Designer Upgrade Guide
  2. Then you can modify the "sapFontFamily" parameter as the font that you desired in UI Theme Designer.

Note: Customizing the Font size and Style is not possible from UI Theme Designer. You can do it via custom CSS, but please be aware that SAP is not responsible for issues caused by it and is not upgrade safe.

entry.title: Custom CDS view for 4JJ Scope item
entry.content:
Hi Team,

I am currently working on mass creation of time sheet entries (4JJ) using SAP BTP Business Process Automation. For this scenario, I need to create a custom CDS view (YY1_TIME_BILL_STATUS).

My initial plan was to use the standard CDS view I_RRBCostDynamicItem as the primary data source. However, I have learned that this view is deprecated and not released, since it belongs to the old Intercompany Billing (ICO) solution. The only field I require from this view is RRBDynamicItem.

Given that I_RRBCostDynamicItem is no longer available, I would like to know how best to replace this field in line with the new ICO solution. Specifically:

  • Can the BillingDocumentItem field from the I_BillingDocumentItem CDS view be used as a replacement for RRBDynamicItem in my scenario?
  • Is this the recommended approach for building the custom CDS view?

    Any guidance or best practices on how to adapt this requirement to the new ICO solution would be greatly appreciated.

     

    Regards,

    Gunadharshini

entry.title: Re: Why is the "create button" not displayed in CDSView?
entry.content:
Dear @AkiraMatsuda,

Why the Create / Copy / Delete buttons are missing, in Public Cloud:

  • Key user extensibility apps (including Custom CDS Views F1866A) are read-only in the productive system
  • You can only create or change Custom CDS Views in the Extensibility system:
    • 2-system landscape ‚Üí Test/Quality system
    • 3-system landscape ‚Üí Development / Customizing tenant

SAP Notes and SAP Community explicitly describe exactly your symptom: ‚ÄúCreate/Edit/Delete buttons are disabled or missing‚Äù in Custom CDS Views in the productive tenant.

More details below from SAP Note and SAP Community:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2553539

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/custom-cds-views-faq/ba-p/13546765

Please confirm that the buttons are missing in the Production environment.

What you should do:

  1. Check which tenant you are logged into:
    • In Fiori Launchpad: user icon (top right) ‚Üí About ‚Üí check System ID / Tenant type
    • Make sure you are in the Extensibility Development / Quality system, not Production
  2. Log on to the correct system:
    • Use your Quality/Test (2-system) or Development/Customizing (3-system) tenant.
    • Open Custom CDS Views F1866A. The Create / Copy / Delete buttons should appear.
  3. (If this is a Starter or Demo system)
    • Extensibility may be turned off. Use the Extensibility Settings app to activate Key User Extensibility for the tenant.

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3342103

       4. Transport to Production

Summary: You can‚Äôt enable the Create button in your productive tenant. You must create and maintain Custom CDS Views in the designated extensibility (Dev/QA) tenant and then transport them.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Public API Missing for Quantity Confirmation Cancellation in SAP DM
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

we‚Äôre currently facing a limitation in SAP Digital Manufacturing: there is no public API available to cancel quantity confirmations.

For Goods Issue and Goods Receipt, SAP DM already provides official cancel APIs ‚Äî but there is no equivalent public endpoint for Quantity Confirmation Cancellation.
We noticed that an internal/private API exists (/sapdmdmemanagecancellation/.../quantityConfirmation/cancel), but without a public interface, it‚Äôs not usable in productive scenarios.

Why is this an issue for us?
Our production processes require fully automated cancellation of previously reported quantities.
At the moment, this is only possible through the Manage Cancellation app, which:

  • cannot be integrated into production processes

  • cannot be embedded in custom UIs or plugins

  • forces manual steps

  • increases the risk of errors and delays in the process

I‚Äôve already created an SAP Influence Request for this:
Influence Request: 361461 

My questions to the community:

  • Are you facing the same limitation?

  • Do you rely on automated cancellation of quantity confirmations as well?

  • Have you found any workarounds that do not depend on the Manage Cancellation app?

Any feedback is appreciated ‚Äî the more visible the demand, the higher the chance SAP will consider exposing this functionality via a public API.

Thanks
Daniel

entry.title: Congratulations, SAP Readiness Check!
entry.content:
As we get ready to celebrate the 100,000th SAP Readiness Check analysis processed, we would like to pause with a brief look at our milestone moments.

Following the release of SAP S/4HANA 1609, customers understood that SAP S/4HANA is different from SAP ECC and started asking questions about the impact of making the move and whether their systems were ready to undergo the transition. These inquiries led to the introduction of the SAP Readiness Check in 2017 as a manual service session to prepare service deliveries for MaxAttention customers looking to convert to SAP S/4HANA.

The first, semi-automated version of SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA went live in May 2019. Since then, SAP Readiness Check has continued to evolve, not only extending the depth of the checks but on top making SAP Readiness Check available for transitions beyond the conversion to SAP S/4HANA, expanding the coverage of SAP products and solutions to SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Supply Chain solutions, SAP Customer Experience solutions, SAP BW/4HANA, and SAP Cloud ALM. As of today, SAP Readiness Check is available on SAP for Me and SAP Cloud ALM, offering nine variants to support various transformation scenarios and has supported over 15,500 customers across 150 countries/regions.

And there‚Äôs more on the roadmap: In the future, we are planning to use genAI features in SAP Readiness Check that will guide users during setup, interpretation, and follow-up tasks. Furthermore, new SAP Readiness Check scenarios for RISE with SAP and SAP Business Suite customers are in the pipeline, evolving SAP Readiness Check to a continual source of information for customers, partners, and SAP teams to discuss where and how further SAP Business Suite products and offerings could optimize and enhance the customer‚Äôs active business processes. Stay tuned for more to come that supports the transition to new SAP solutions!

‚ÄúSAP Readiness Check is a cornerstone of every successful SAP S/HANA transformation we support‚Äù, states Markus Schuetz, Senior Lead Architect at the SAP Partner Claranet Addon GmbH and workstream lead of the DSAG (German SAP User Group).

A big thank you to all customers and partners trusting in SAP Readiness Check as the basis for planning and preparing the transition to new strategic SAP solutions and into the cloud, and congratulations to all SAP colleagues contributing to the continuous success of SAP Readiness Check!

We invite you to comment on this blog to share your congrats, thoughts, and SAP Readiness Check success stories with the SAP Readiness Check Community!

Your SAP Readiness Check team

entry.title: BAPI for confirming a production order ( CO11N )
entry.content:
I‚Äôm working on a .NET solution using the SAP .NET Connector (NCo) to confirm and update production orders and their operation quantities (yield, scrap, and rework).

I‚Äôm using the following BAPIs:

  • BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_TT

  • BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_HDR

I‚Äôm updating the TIMETICKETS table for BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_TT and the ATHDRLEVELS table for BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_HDR, setting all relevant field values.

When I execute these BAPIs, I receive a success message:
"Confirmation of order [OrderId] saved."

However, when I check transaction CO15, the confirmation is created, but the values are not the same as those I passed to the BAPI functions. Only the yield is recorded, and it reflects the total planned output quantity of the production order, rather than the specific quantities (yield, scrap, rework) that I provided during execution.

I‚Äôm committing the transaction using:

BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT
f.SetValue("WAIT", "X");
f.Invoke(dest);

(dest is an RfcDestination)

I get the same result when testing these functions in transaction SE37.

What am I missing or doing wrong?

Thanks for your help!

entry.title: SAP BTP Joule Setup Failure - Error
entry.content:
SAP BTP Joule Setup Failure - Error  

This document summarizes the issue encountered during the Joule setup in SAP BTP, including error details and screenshots for incident submission. 

 

Error Summary 

 

During the execution of the 'Setting Up Joule' booster, the process failed during SaaS Subscription creation. 

 

 

 

Error Message 

 

Unexpected state UPDATE_PARAMETERS_FAILED occurred while trying to create the subscription to application das-application-ias.  

 

 

 

Automation GUID 

 

4b22917f-c0a-4111-baee-2c5fe758647d 

 

Expected Behavior 

 

- The booster should successfully create the das-application-ias SaaS subscription. 

- All booster steps should complete and show green status. 

- Joule should become available for configuration within the subaccount. 

 

Actual Behavior 

 

- SaaS Subscription step failed with status UPDATE_PARAMETERS_FAILED. 

- Remaining integration steps were skipped automatically. 

- Joule provisioning never completed.  

 

 

 

 

Impact on System 

 

- Joule cannot be deployed or used in the current BTP landscape. 

- Subaccount provisioning is incomplete. 

- Further integrations depending on Joule cannot be configured. 

- Delays implementation timelines. 

 

Troubleshooting Already Attempted 

 

- Retried booster execution. 

- Validated entitlements (AI Core, AI Launchpad, Identity Services). 

- Checked IAS trust configuration. 

- Verified subaccount exists and is accessible. 

- No custom configurations that should interfere with SaaS subscription logic. 

 

Request to SAP Support 

- Investigate the UPDATE_PARAMETERS_FAILED error during subscription creation. 

- Validate the backend provisioning logs for automation request GUID 4b22917f-c0a-4111-baee-2c5fe758647d. 

- Confirm if any configuration or entitlement is missing for the target region.

entry.title: Statutory Reporting and EFD-Reinf: Mass Rectification for the R-4000 Series
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We're excited to share a new feature in the EFD-Reinf report for Brazil, specifically for users of the Statutory Reporting framework: Mass Rectification for the R-4000 Series. This enhancement is set to transform how you manage corrections for the EFD-Reinf R-4000 series.

Introducing Mass Rectification in R-4000 Series

With the new Mass Rectification functionality, users can now easily generate rectification files for multiple events at once during the Correction Phase of your reporting tasks. This means faster and more efficient handling of corrections when you need to rectify several events for a given company and branch.

How It Works

When running the Brazil EFD-Reinf Periodic Files task, you'll notice a new Run Mass Rectification checkbox in the selection criteria popup, as seen below:

Here‚Äôs what you need to know about the options:

  • File ID for Rectification:
    • When a specific File ID is entered in this field, the system will create the rectification file only for the provided File ID (i.e., only the selected event will be corrected). 
  • Run Mass Rectification Checkbox:
    • If you select the Run Mass Rectification flag without entering a File ID, rectification files will be generated for all eligible R-4000 series events for the specified Company Code and Business Place.
    • This is especially useful when multiple corrections are needed across several events, saving you significant manual effort!

Additionally, you can schedule or run this task immediately with the standard Run Options for background processing that is recommend for large volume of files, making it even easier to fit rectification into your processes.

Why Use Mass Rectification?

  • Faster Corrections: Generate rectification files for many events in a single run.
  • Greater Flexibility: Correct either specific events by ID or all relevant events for your company and branch at once.
  • Improved Compliance: Stay up to date with changing requirements and ensure your data is always accurate.

Learn More

To explore this new functionality and stay updated on further enhancements, check out these SAP Help Portal resources:

  • Document and Reporting Compliance
  • EFD-Reinf Report

 

We value your feedback!
If you have any questions or suggestions for future topics, please leave your comment below.

See you in the next post!



Statutory Reporting for Brazil Team

entry.title: Re: Individual usage record with allowance template
entry.content:

yes this is the expected behaviour. For scenarios where usage is rated individually, allowances are not considered. 
The reason is that usage records with rating type Individual can have items having quantity fields to be used for pricing, and there is no way to configure which quantity field is the relevant one to consider during allowance allocation. 

Meanwhile we improved the documentation as previously this piece of information was not easy to find.

Best regards,
Carsten

entry.title: Re: Material availability check in maintenance orders ‚Äì S...
entry.content:
Dear @saraserrano,

What you want is standard in Public Cloud but it works via an ATP check that updates dedicated material availability system statuses on the order (MSPT = Material shortage, MACM = Material committed, etc.). There is no customizing in Public Cloud to run this check live at order creation like in Private Cloud, instead you use Fiori apps and a scheduled job.

For maintenance orders you have dedicated material availability system statuses at order header, for example:

  • I0004 / MSPT - Material shortage
  • I0340 / MACM - Material committed
  • I0420 / MANC - Material availability not checked
  • I0485 / NMAT - No material components

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/6e25338332644773968319fe2d9b0dab.html

These statuses are:

  • Updated automatically when a material availability check is executed for the order
  • Visible in the order header (Change Maintenance Order app)

So your status Material shortage is exactly MSPT, which is set by the system when the check finds missing parts.

Where you see availability:

In Change Maintenance Order app:

  • You can Display Material Availability (IWBK) for the order.

 

  • After you run the check and save the order, if components are missing, the system sets MSPT Material shortage on the order header.

More details below in SAP Note:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003290734

In planning apps / backlog

Planners typically work from list/scheduling apps, where availability is summarized:

  • Manage Maintenance Notifications and Orders and Manage Maintenance Backlog

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/d8a94ddd0c514780a9836aa04524f96f.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/02eb6fdf89c147d7a51252c4b672bc6b.html

  • Resource scheduling apps (Manage Work Center Utilization, Manage Schedules, Maintenance Scheduling Board, Assign Maintenance Order Operations) show the Material Availability Status

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/8502afe99f714fde977d8344c340b34f.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/b2800e0b1d114308ad6e8e959ad2f476.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/03f2d1580255033be10000000a4450e5.html

This is typically where planners filter for Material Shortage to see all orders with missing stock.

How to get automatic Material shortage with standard. The key building block is the Fiori app Schedule Material Availability Check (F2465):

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/756fca81b45b4477a5f2060d36e4edde.html

 

  1. Open Schedule Material Availability Check
  2. Create a job using the template Material Availability Check for Maintenance Orders

 

  1. In the template you can:
    • Restrict by order type, phase etc.
  2. Define scheduling options for your scenario

 

When this job runs, it:

  • Performs an ATP check for all selected maintenance orders

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/756fca81b45b4477a5f2060d36e4edde.html

  • Updates the material availability system status on each order header
  • Makes that status visible:
    • in Change Maintenance Order app
    • in Manage Maintenance Backlog app

With this in place your requirement is covered in standard:

  • Materials not available ->job sets MSPT = Material shortage automatically.
  • Planners see this status directly in the order and in their backlogs.

Summary, with this you get:

  • Availability visible directly in the maintenance order
  • Automatic update of the status to Material shortage (MSPT) when parts are not available driven by the standard material availability check logic and scheduled job.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Beyond Revenue: Manage Your Pipeline by Quantity with SAP‚Äôs New Volume Pipeline Manager
entry.content:
Why Volume Pipeline Manager?

Our traditional pipeline manager tracks revenue, but for bulk sellers, that‚Äôs only half the story. If your goal is to deliver 140,000 liters in Q4, you need visibility into quantities ‚Äì not just deal size. The Volume Pipeline Manager solves this by letting you manage your pipeline based on total quantity.

Prerequisites:

  • Define a tenant-wide default unit of measure (e.g., liters).
  • Set conversion rules to liters in product master if needed.
  • Maintain quantities in the default or a physically related unit of measure (e.g., gallons ‚Üí liters) per line item.

Key Capabilities

  • Interactive Bubble Chart: Visualize opportunities by quantity and time period for quick trend analysis.
  • Opportunity List View: Edit details like phase, forecast category, and close date directly.
  • Sales Unit/Territory Rollup [Only Sales Managers]: Break down pipeline by unit or territory for better forecasting.
  • Totals Breakdown [Only Sales Managers]: See aggregate totals by account, owner, document type, and sales phase.

Benefits

  • Improved Forecasting: Plan with confidence using accurate quantity-based insights.
  • Better Opportunity Management: Focus on high-volume deals that matter most.
  • Higher Productivity: Enable data-driven decisions and trend identification.

In Action: A Sales Manager‚Äôs Day

Imagine you‚Äôre a Sales Manager at Best Run Business reviewing your Q4 pipeline:

  1. Spot At-Risk Opportunities: Alpha Brewery‚Äôs large deal needs attention ‚Äì the last customer interaction was weeks ago.
  2. Check Pipeline Coverage: Target is 140,000 liters; with 68,000 won and 150,000 committed, you‚Äôre on track.
  3. Ensure Fair Distribution: Sarah may need coaching; Bella‚Äôs pipeline looks challenging.
  4. Drill into Product Demand: Emmanuel from production calls about the demand for Hefeweizen this month. A quick filter shows 14,000 liters committed between Alpha and Campon. 

What‚Äôs Next for Volume Pipeline Manager?

We‚Äôre taking pipeline visibility to the next level. Upcoming enhancements include:

  • Target Visibility in Pipeline Manager: Compare pipeline against targets directly within the dashboard for instant performance tracking.
  • Totals Breakdown by Product and Product Group: Go beyond opportunity-level insights ‚Äì understand how each product contributes to your pipeline.

The Bottom Line

The Volume Pipeline Manager introduces a new way for sales managers and reps ‚Äì particularly those focused on a single product type ‚Äì to manage their pipeline. By shifting the emphasis from revenue to quantity, it adds a critical dimension for planning and execution. This capability was built in response to customer feedback, ensuring it solves real challenges for bulk sellers and delivers actionable insights for smarter, faster decisions.

entry.title: Modernizing Spartacus: Practical Gains from Angular 17‚Äì19 Control Flow and Deferred Rendering
entry.content:
Introduction :-

Spartacus storefronts often rely on dynamic components such as product detail sections, personalized CMS blocks, and multi-step checkout flows. Optimizing how and when these components render is essential for improving load times and maintaining an efficient user experience.

Angular‚Äôs newer features offer several advantages:

  • Reduced initial bundle size

  • Improved rendering behavior

  • Cleaner and more maintainable templates

  • Better runtime performance and SSR compatibility

    These improvements directly support the performance requirements of modern Spartacus implementations.

    Deferred Loading in Angular :-

    Deferred loading enables parts of the UI to be loaded only when needed. Spartacus storefronts benefit significantly from this, especially for below-the-fold components or sections not required during initial paint.

    Deferring Spartacus Components :-

    Angular 17 Example :-

    Angular 17 introduced the @defer  syntax:

    @defer (on viewport) {
  <cx-product-reviews></cx-product-reviews>
} 
    @placeholder {
  <div class="skeleton skeleton-reviews"></div>
} 
    @error {
  <div>Unable to load reviews at this time.</div>
}

    This approach avoids loading non-critical components until they are visible.

    Angular 19 Enhancements :-

    Angular 19 keeps the same syntax but improves deferred view hydration, error handling, and prefetching behavior.

    @defer (on interaction) {
  <cx-order-history></cx-order-history>
} 
    @placeholder {
  <div>Loading...</div>
}

    These improvements are especially beneficial for Spartacus SSR deployments.

    Modern Angular Template Syntax :-

    Angular‚Äôs new control flow syntax (@IF,  @FOR,  @switch) simplifies templates and delivers performance benefits over the traditional structural directives. These enhancements create more predictable rendering paths and reduce change detection overhead.

    Conditional Rendering with @IF :-

    Angular 17 Example :-

    @if (isLoggedIn$ | async) {
  <cx-navigation></cx-navigation>
} @else {
  <cx-login-register></cx-login-register>
}

    Angular 19 Behavior :-

    While the syntax remains the same, Angular 19 provides better diagnostics, stronger type-checking, and improved runtime performance.

    @if (cartLoaded$ | async) {
  <cx-cart-details></cx-cart-details>
} @else {
  <div class="loading">Loading cart...</div>
}

    Rendering Lists with @FOR :-

    Angular 17 Example :-

    @for (banner of banners; track banner.uid) {
  <cx-banner [banner]="banner"></cx-banner>
}

    Angular 19 Enhancements :-

    Angular 19 optimizes list diffing and supports more reliable hydration:

    @for (product of products; track product.code) {
  <cx-product-list-item [product]="product"></cx-product-list-item>
}
     
    Practical Example: Improving a Spartacus Product Detail Page :-

    Before (Traditional Structural Directives and Eager Loading) :-

    <cx-product-summary *ngIf="product$ | async as product"></cx-product-summary>

    <cx-product-images></cx-product-images>

    <cx-product-reviews></cx-product-reviews>

    After (Using Modern Template Syntax and Deferred Loading) :-

    @if (product$ | async as product) 
    {
  <cx-product-summary [product]="product"></cx-product-summary>
}

    <cx-product-images></cx-product-images>

    @defer (on viewport) {
  <cx-product-reviews></cx-product-reviews>
} 
    @placeholder {
  <div class="loading">Loading reviews...</div>
}

    This provides cleaner template structure and improves overall page performance, especially for initial load and Core Web Vitals.

    Conclusion :-

    Angular‚Äôs modern features ‚Äî particularly deferred loading and the updated template syntax ‚Äî offer clear advantages for Spartacus implementations. While Angular 17 introduces these capabilities, Angular 19 refines them, providing better hydration, more efficient rendering, and stronger developer tooling.

    For Spartacus storefronts that rely heavily on dynamic content and complex templates, adopting these Angular improvements results in:

    • Faster initial load

    • Reduced JavaScript execution

    • Clearer and more maintainable code

    • More predictable SSR and hydration behavior

entry.title: From Tactical to Strategic: The Future of Procurement and Accounts Payable
entry.content:
From Tactical to Strategic: The Future of Procurement and Accounts Payable üöÄ

In today‚Äôs rapidly evolving business landscape, the transformation of procurement and accounts payable (AP) functions is more than just a technological upgrade‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategic imperative. The recent episode of SAP‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Future of Procurement‚Äù podcast, featuring Mike Jasper, Director of Transformation Product and Client Success at Extropy Advisors, dives deep into how organizations can shift from tactical operations to strategic value creation. Here‚Äôs what you need to know.

Shifting the Paradigm: From Manual Tasks to Strategic Impact üîÑ

Historically, procurement and AP have been viewed as transactional, paper-pushing departments. Mike highlights that while procurement has evolved from ‚Äúpurchasing agents‚Äù focused on bids and POs, AP is still often stuck in manual, tactical activities. The key to unlocking strategic value? Automation. By automating invoice processing and data entry, AP teams can redirect their efforts toward activities that drive cost savings and business growth. This shift not only increases efficiency but also empowers AP to contribute to broader financial strategies.

The Power of Collaboration: Breaking Down Silos ü§ù

A recurring theme in the discussion is the importance of collaboration between procurement, AP, and finance. Mike and the panel emphasize that working together uncovers opportunities for working capital improvements, such as payment term extensions and early payment discounts. When departments align their KPIs and share data, they can collectively optimize supplier relationships, reduce late payments, and negotiate better terms. The creation of shared dashboards and procurement intelligence platforms fosters transparency and mutual understanding, driving both operational and strategic benefits.

Overcoming Resistance: Building Trust in Automation and AI üõ°Ô∏è

Change management is a critical challenge. Many AP professionals fear that automation and AI will lead to job loss or errors in financial reporting. Mike suggests a gradual approach‚Äîautomate in stages, track accuracy, and build trust by demonstrating that technology can handle routine tasks reliably. By quantifying success and focusing on exceptions, organizations can help AP teams see the value in shifting their focus from manual checks to strategic initiatives. AI is poised to revolutionize AP by enabling smarter data validation, predictive coding, and holistic financial insights‚Äîprovided that organizations invest in clean, integrated data.

Forward-Looking Insights: The Road Ahead for AP and Procurement üåê

Looking to the future, Mike offers a bold prediction: AP and procurement may eventually merge into a single, strategic department. As automation and AI continue to advance, the boundaries between these functions will blur, enabling seamless collaboration and more impactful contributions to corporate strategy. The move toward digital payments, such as ACH and virtual cards, is accelerating, with the U.S. finally surpassing the halfway mark for non-check payments. However, there‚Äôs still work to be done to fully digitize and optimize payment processes.

Conclusion: Embracing Change for Lasting Value üí°

The journey from tactical to strategic in procurement and AP is ongoing, but the destination promises greater efficiency, stronger supplier relationships, and enhanced business outcomes. Organizations that embrace automation, foster collaboration, and build trust in new technologies will be well-positioned to lead in the future of spend management. As Mike and the podcast panel remind us, the goal isn‚Äôt to eliminate jobs‚Äîit‚Äôs to make them more impactful and rewarding. Now is the time to clean your POs, accelerate approvals, and realize those cost savings. Are you ready to be a change agent in your organization?

What are your thoughts on the future of procurement and AP? Share your experiences and join the conversation! Send your feedback, questions and topic ideas to TheFutureofProcurement@SAP.com

üåê OpenSAP: https://podcast.opensap.info/future-of-procurement/

üçé Apple Podcasts: https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/episode-23-from-tactical-to-strategic-with-mike-jasper/id1764078646?i=1000736234046

Spotify:  https://open.spotify.com/show/5twXP1NehSqgCAznTnzQ5H

entry.title: Re: Monitor rating app
entry.content:
Hi Ankit, 

rating errors should be an exceptional case, especially in situations where the pricing configuration is not working as expected. 
Typically such problems are resolved in test systems before productive use of a pricing scheme.

Because of the worklist and the performance of the whole app, the restriction to 500 entries were chosen. Also, there are limitations regarding the number of retries you can trigger in one go. 
Do you expect that many of these usage records would run into a rating error? What would be the action to resolve the situation in your case?

Best regards, 
Carsten

entry.title: SAP Fiori development newsletter November 2025 (issue #37)
entry.content:
We are in the midst of ‚Äúconference season‚Äù, so this means lots of great announcements about new innovations. See the events section below for details on the European and U.S. iterations.

If you are looking to try the latest AI-powered development tools, such as MCP servers, please join us at our next SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf on December 9. This is a great way to learn about where to focus your learning resources in 2026 and what tools you can use to accelerate your development projects.

For ongoing updates, I encourage you to join our monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable. Register online or email me for an invitation.

If you prefer to receive this in your inbox, please subscribe to the SAP Fiori development newsletter.

Development news

Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal
In this 6-part series, Katrin Polloczek and Marcel Waechter provide a thorough look at the new SAP Fiori development portal, which replaces the Flexible Programming Model Explorer. The series covers building blocks, floor plans, extension options, custom pages, and how all these pieces fit together. Read more.

Installing SAPUI5 patches is now better in every respect
For years, the MIME repository has been the standard location for storing SAPUI5 runtime artifacts for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. Although the MIME repository has served its purpose, many customers working with SAPUI5, especially system operators installing new SAPUI5 patches, face challenges. Now, the UI5 team introduces the SAPUI5 Runtime Repository to improve this in every respect: Angelika Kirilin explains.

Goodbye UI5 tooling - Hello UI5 CLI
Over the last decade, UI5 Tooling became the best-in-class tool to develop UI5 projects. It offers a range of features to make your life as a developer easy when serving and building projects. It turned out that the name UI5 Tooling led to much confusion and even support requests. The UI5 team settled for a new name "UI5 CLI" to align with industry best practices. See details.

Start your SAPUI5 coding journey in the SAPUI5 Demo Kit
The SAPUI5 SDK, or the Demo Kit, is the one-stop shop for modern developers who want to build state-of-the-art enterprise-grade SAP applications. Discover the features.

Streamlining local app previews: virtual endpoints for seamless development
In traditional app development setup, local app previews and testing rely heavily on physical sandbox files. While this method provides a level of consistency and stability, it often falls short in terms of up-to-dateness and maintenance effort. This post explores a new approach to local app previews and testing, which can now be virtually served by middleware. Learn more.

Events

Register for SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf (customers and sponsoring partners only): 
‚Äãhttps://events.sap.com/eur-fiori-innovation-day-walldorf-2025/en_us/home.html

In case you missed it 

SAP TechEd summary articles
ASUG Tech Connect in Louisville, Kentucky, USA, had lots of great content on vibe coding, the evolution of SAP Fiori, and lots of hands-on sessions to test SAP‚Äôs latest development tools and technologies.

The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build
If you‚Äôre an SAPUI5 developer and couldn‚Äôt attend SAP TechEd in Berlin, here‚Äôs one highlight you can watch as a replay: A deep dive session on ‚ÄúThe art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build‚Äù: https://www.sap.com/events/teched/virtual/flow/sap/tev25/catalog-virtual/page/catalog/session/1752166265407001r3vW

Back issues from the past year

SAP Fiori development newsletter September 2025 (issue #36)

SAP Fiori development newsletter July 2025 (issue #35)

SAP FIori development newsletter May 2025 (Issue #34)

SAP Fiori development newsletter March 2025 (Issue #33)

SAP Fiori development newsletter January 2025 (issue #32)

SAP Fiori development newsletter November 2024 (issue #31)

entry.title: Unsupported OData Version 4.01 when connecting Fiori List Report app to Sales Order API
entry.content:
Dear Community,

I‚Äôm currently working on a specific development in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
we are developing a Fiori app that allows users to mass change sales order items (quantity, delivery date, add new items, etc.).

For this purpose, we are using SAP Business Application Studio.
We first created a List Report application, then connected it to an OData service using the following API:
https://myxxxxxx-api.s4hana.cloud.sap/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_salesorder/srvd_a2x/sap/salesorder/0001/

However, when running the application, we receive the following error message:

‚ÄúCould not open app. Please try again later. Details‚Äù

 

Could you please help me understand this behavior and guide us on how to resolve this issue?
